awd_titl_txt: Direct In Situ Analysis of Surface Flow Fields in Deformation Processing of Lightweight Structural Metals
awd_abstract_narration:
Light-weight structural alloys of aluminum, magnesium and titanium are of technological interest for use in applications in the discrete products sector, encompassing automotive, aerospace, energy systems and biomedical applications. Deformation processes such as extrusion, rolling, sheet-metal working, and forming methods are typically used to shape components from these metallic systems during manufacturing. The surface quality attributes of components, such as defects, finish and strength, created by the processes is to a large extent determined by the nature of metal flow at the surface. This surface flow also plays a major role in controlling friction and wear at the forming interfaces. For these reasons, there is a critical need for studying the fundamental nature of the flow in deformation processing so that component and product quality can be enhanced by suitable control of the flow. This award will address this need by supporting research to advancing the state-of-the-art of manufacturing process technologies in key industrial sectors. Complementing the research is an education program involving undergraduate researchers in creating a video gallery of flows for industry, and a modest focus on fostering entrepreneurship in graduate study. 

The research will study a model process system - a hard die (wedge) sliding against a workpiece - with three coordinated thrusts.  Firstly, a deformation science initiative will utilize in situ observational techniques for high-resolution analysis of flow at workpiece surfaces and contacts. Flow phenomena (e.g., laminar, sinuous, instabilities), strain and strain rate fields, at the surfaces will be analyzed as a function of controllable process parameters. The interplay between flow type, friction, and defect formation will be explored. Secondly, workpiece surface quality will be examined in terms of microstructure, defect structures, mechanical properties, and topography. The surface quality attributes will be correlated with the flow fields. Thirdly, surface flow will be modeled using continuum approaches that incorporate material heterogeneity and grain level structure. By integrating the analyses results, a processing map, that demarcates flows and defects in terms of key material and process parameters, will be created. The study will be conducted specifically on model low-density structural alloys of aluminum, magnesium and titanium, selected for their experimental suitability and direct relevance to weight reduction in the discrete products sector. The techniques and findings will impact areas as diverse as materials processing, tribology, plasticity, and geophysical folding phenomena.

por.por_cntn:
There are many instances in advanced manufacturing and materials processing where structural metals are subjected to large shape changes in their transformation to finished products. Examples of such shape transformations occur in deformation processing, machining, comminution and surface engineering, and span application domains such as aerospace, automotive, energy systems and biomedical. Permanent plastic deformation is intrinsic to these shape changes and applications, with plastic strains of 1-10 being typical. When such large strains are imposed in metals especially near surfaces, unsteady modes of plastic flow are often the form with adverse impacts on deformation energy and workpiece surface quality.

In this study, we have developed high-resolution, high-speed imaging techniques, for characterizing large-strain plastic deformation at and near surfaces, quantitatively, under loading conditions typical of forming, machining and sliding processes. The techniques provide deformation and shape-change information over spatial regions as large as 1.5 mm by 1.5 mm, and at spatial resolution of ~ one micrometer. They can be applied to also study deformation at the grain-level (microscale) and how this microscale deformation is coupled to plastic flow at the mesoscale (millimeter length scale). The techniques have been applied to study nucleation and propagation of unsteady (non-uniform) plastic deformation modes, and material flow and friction in the vicinity of die/tool walls in processing. Besides the well-known case of shear banding, three other distinct unsteady flow modes have been identified and characterized ? sinuous flow, plastic buckling at surfaces, and fracture by flow localization. Sinuous flow is an unsteady mesoscale flow mode characterized by large-amplitude folding and vortex-like flow components which is nucleated by plastic buckling of material in the process deformation zone at the surface. This flow mode involves large-energy dissipation and extensive redundant deformation. The latter pertains to non shape-change related deformation. We show that this type of flow is widely prevalent in large-strain deformation of ductile and/or highly strain-hardening metals. Similarities and contrasts between sinuous flow and shear banding, in terms of strain, rotations and energy dissipation, are highlighted using the in situ observational techniques. These observations are first-of-a-kind, and explain how macroscopic parameters such as forces, energy and workpiece surface quality in deformation processing and machining are related to the micro/meso scale deformation modes.  The observations have also revealed the occurrence of plastic boundary layers in the vicinity of die/tool walls and how these boundary layers determine the frictional energy dissipation at these walls/interfaces. The dynamics of unsteady flows near metal surfaces, e.g., folding, show strong similarities with flow phenomena in geophysical systems. The imaging techniques can be applied to varied domains beyond manufacturing and materials processing, such as friction phenomena in sliding, materials testing and fracture/failures.

Based on fundamental understanding of how unsteady flows develop, we have formulated methods to suppress as well as enhance unsteady flows. One approach to suppression involves modification of the surface deformation geometry through application of a physical (die) constraint to the surface deformation. This approach has been successfully used to suppress shear banding and sinuous flow modes, and achieve uniformity of surface deformation resulting in a laminar flow mode prevailing. The benefits of this suppression include new energy-efficient methods for creating metal sheet and foil, using shear-based deformation processing, from material systems such as aluminum, titanium, magnesium and advanced electrical steels. Unsteady flows can also be modulated to produce fracture in the deformation zone and limit highly dissipative plastic deformation. This modulation has been demonstrated by application of common organic media to the metal surface in the deformation zone. The organic media promote fracture via local embrittlement of the metal. This approach is shown to have important benefits for energy-efficient machining and comminution of soft ?gummy? metals such as aluminum, copper, stainless steels and tantalum, which are otherwise difficult to process despite being relatively soft.

The flow control methods have been patented. Based on the understanding gained of unsteady flow phenomena, we are developing new energy-efficient materials processing methods for manufacturing of metal sheet, foil, wire and fiber. New chemo-mechanically assisted cutting and comminution processes are another outcome that we hope to achieve with metals, with fruitful prospects for commercialization.

The observational techniques have also led to creation of a number of videos of plastic flow phenomena in metals which have been extensively disseminated to the general public via the web. One of the videos related to fracture of glass drops has received more than 3 million views and was selected as a video chart-topper for 2017 by Science Magazine. Another video related to a mechanochemical effect in metals has received more than one million views. Several publications resulting from the work have been the subject of commentaries in science and technology magazines, and the popular including Science, Smithsonian Magazine, Phys.Org, NPR (WBAA), Modern Machine Shop and Washington Post.
